Commenting on Saul Steinberg’s works he wrote, ‘Let us be honest with ourselves. These drawings are for advanced, refined tastes … To thousands of ordinary fair-goers they are puzzling.

Khrushchev was particularly critical of Stalinist architecture in his 1954 speech at the All-Union Conference of Builders. He disapproved of the ornate facades and spires, saying they reminded him of ‘ecclesiastical architecture’. Lengthy English-language excerpts from this speech are at http://volumeproject.org/2009/00/00/Industrialised+Building+Speech,+1954/7783 (accessed 1 August 2011).

A fascinating study of the Soviet pavilion is S.E. Reid, ‘The Soviet Pavilion at Brussels ’58: Convergence, Conversion, Critical Assimilation or Acculturation?’, CWIHP Working Paper #62, http://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/WP62_Reid_web_V3sm.pdf (accessed 1 August 2011). See also the article by L. Siegelbaum in this special issue. Useful primary sources for exploring the Soviet pavilion are the many brochures that the Soviets made available in English, French and German at EXPO ’58, including Ausstellung der Werke der Bildenden Kunst der UdSSR: Katalog (no place of publication 1958), or the weekly exposition newspaper, Sputnik. A photo of a main entry mural with red flags and children in red scarves is in K. Rozhdestvenskii, ‘Vystavochnie inter’ery Briusselia,’ Dekorativnoe iskusstvo SSSR 1, 12 (1958), 10. One of the ‘piknik’ is found in V. Makarevich, ‘Masterstvo ekspozitsii’, Dekorativnoe iskusstvo SSSR, 1, 12 (1958), 15.

Out of 20 possible points, Czechoslovakia received 18.72; Belgium’s Civil Engineering pavilion received 18.37; Great Britain 18.32; West Germany and the United States 18.28; and the Soviet Union, coming in thirteenth place, 17.59 points. Pavilions with more than 18 points all received a Gold Star. See National Archive of the Czech Republic (hereafter NA), KSČ – Ústřední výbor 1945–1989, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 190/261/5, ‘Zpráva o dalším průběhu Světové výstavy v Bruselu s vyhodnocením československých národních dnů’. The Czechoslovaks received a total of 171 prizes, including 52 Grand Prizes, 36 Honorable Diplomas, 35 Gold Medals, 23 Silver Medals and 15 Bronze Medals. China did not participate in EXPO ’58.

The survey results are in the USIA Historical Collection, ‘Visitor Reaction to the U.S. versus Major Competing Exhibits at the Brussels International Fair’ (July, 1958). USIA conducted a second set of interviews from September 19 to 29 (this time with 1233 visitors). Again, the Czechoslovak pavilion was rated ‘the most excellent’, although this time a different set of pavilions followed. In order after Czechoslovakia came Great Britain, Switzerland and France. The United States was in fifth place with a very narrow lead over the sixth-placed Soviet Union. See USIA Historical Collection, ‘Follow-Up Study of Visitor Reaction to the U.S. Versus Major Competing Exhibits at the Brussels International Fair’ (June, 1959).

The literature on the Czechoslovak pavilion is fairly extensive, although mostly in Czech. To commemorate the recent 50th anniversary of the pavilion’s success, two important exhibitions were held in Prague. The exhibition catalogues are D. Kramerová and V. Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen: Československá účast na světové výstavě EXPO 58 v Bruselu a životní styl 1. poloviny 60. let (Prague 2008); and E. Benešová and K. Šimůnková, EXPO ’58: Příběh československé účasti na Světové výstavě v Bruselu (Prague 2008). A small, useful pamphlet, produced for the 40th anniversary of EXPO ’58 is R. Sedláková and R. Váňa, Život v rytmu atomu (Prague 1998). A very valuable older work by one of the creators of the Czechoslovak pavilion is J. Santar, Světová výstava v Bruselu: EXPO 58 (Prague 1961). Recent articles treating the Czechoslovak pavilion include D. Kramerová, ‘Otevírání cesty: Světová výstava EXPO 58 v Bruselu’, in Dějiny českého výtvarného umění, 1958–2000 Vol. VI/1 (Prague 2007), 71–7; and Rostislav Švácha, ‘Un itinéraire d’outverture et de rapprochement: Le pavillon Tchécoslovaque’, in de Kooning and Devos (eds), L'Architecture moderne à l'Expo 58, 277–86.

Cold War visions of domesticity are discussed in V. de Grazia, Irresistible Empire: America’s Advance through 20th-Century Europe (Cambridge, Mass. 2005). See also R. Oldenziel and K. Zachmann (eds), Cold War Kitchen: Americanization, Technology and European Users (Boston 2009); and P. Betts and D. Crowley (eds), ‘Domestic Dreamworlds: Notions of Home in Post-1945 Europe’, Journal of Contemporary History, 40, 2 (2005), 213–362. Cold War modernism in design is the theme of D. Crowley and J. Pavitt (eds), Cold War Modern: Design, 1945–1970 (London 2008).

György Péteri argues that four elements characterized the socialist system: aims towards rapid modernization; acceptance of Western economic and technological standards of success; ‘administrative coercion,’ rather than free markets, as the force driving economic development; and rivalry with ‘decadent’ capitalism and claims of one day becoming the sole economic system in the world. Certainly the last three are characteristic of socialism in Czechoslovakia; the first element is less applicable due to Czechoslovakia’s more advanced economy before the Second World War. See G. Péteri, ‘Nylon Curtain: Transnational and Transsystemic Tendencies in the Cultural Life of State-Socialist Russia and East-Central Europe’, Slavonica, 10, 2 (2004), 114.

J.Pernes, Krize komunistického režimu v Československu v 50. letech 20. století (Prague 2008); and K. Kaplan, Kronika komunistického Československa: Kořeny reformy 1956–1968, Společnost a moc (Prague 2008). Other important studies of Czechoslovak state-society relations during the 1950s are M. Blaive, Promarněná příležitost: Československo a rok 1956 (Prague 2001); and M. Blaive, Une déstalinisation manquée: Tchécoslovaquie 1956 (Brussels 2005); P. Heumos, ‘Vyhrňme si rukávy, než se kola zastaví!’ Dělníci a státní socialismus v Československu 1945-1968 (Prague 2006); and L. Kalinová, Společenské proměny v čase socialistického experimentu: K sociálním dějinám v letech 1945–1969 (Prague 2007).

Studies treating general cultural politics in Czechoslovakia during the 1950s are J. Knapík, V zajetí moci: Kulturní politika, její systém a aktéři, 1948–1956 (Prague 2006); and A. Kusák, Kultura a politika v Československu, 1945–1956 (Prague 1998). Studies of industrial design in socialist Czechoslovakia are rare, but include the survey of T. Bruthansová and J. Králíček, Czech 100 Design Icons (Prague 2005); articles in Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen; and works by M.Lamarová, including 50. léta: Užité umění a design (Prague 1988). Important works on industrial design in other east-bloc countries are G. Castillo, Cold War on the Home Front: The Soft Power of Midcentury Design (Minneapolis, MN 2010); D. Crowley, ‘“Beauty, Everyday and For All”: The Social Vision of Design in Stalinist Poland’, in J. Attfield (ed.), Utility Reassessed (Manchester 1999), 58–72; and also articles in S.E. Reid and D. Crowley (eds), Style and Socialism: Modernity and Material Culture in Post-War Eastern Europe (Oxford 2000). For the West German case see P. Betts, The Authority of Everyday Objects: A Cultural History of West German Industrial Design (Berkeley, CA 2004).

Socialist realism was an artistic style that relied heavily on figurative depiction to further Communist Party goals. Partisan fighters and soldiers, industrial and agricultural laborers and Communist Party leaders gazing off into the future in heroic, static poses provided much subject matter for socialist realist artists, as did moments important in the Party’s history. Abstract art was condemned as anathema to socialist realism and Party goals, on the grounds that it was bourgeois, counterrevolutionary and difficult for the masses to understand. In the Soviet Union socialist realism became official cultural policy in 1932 following Stalin’s decree, ‘On the Reconstruction of Literary and Art Organizations’. In Czechoslovakia it was made official cultural policy in 1949, thereby having a shorter life and less firm roots there before Stalin’s demise in 1953. Works on socialist realist art in Czechoslovakia are T. Petišková, Československý socialistický realismus 1948–1958 (Prague 2002); and F. Augusto Razetto, Socialistický realismus: Československo 1948–1989 (Prague 2009). Other important works on socialist realism are E. Dobrenko, The Political Economy of Socialist Realism (New Haven, CT 2007); S. Fitzpatrick, ‘Becoming Cultured: Socialist Realism and the Representation of Privilege and Taste’, The Cultural Front: Power and Culture in Revolutionary Russia (Ithaca, N.Y. 1992), 216ff. and T. Lahusen and E. Dobrenko, Socialist Realism without Shores (Durham, NC 1995).

The quotation here is from K. H. Jarausch, ‘Beyond Uniformity: The Challenge of Historicizing the GDR’, in Jarausch (ed.), Dictatorship as Experience: Towards a Socio-Cultural History of the GDR (New York and Oxford 1999), 9. This volume is a seminal collection for the study of state-society relations in East Germany. Others in this large, growing historiography include M. Fulbrook, The People’s State: East German Society from Hitler to Honecker (New Haven 2008); T. Lindenberger (ed.), Herrschaft und Eigen-Sinn in der Diktatur: Studien zur Gellschaftsgeschichte der DDR (Cologne 1999); A. Lüdtke and P. Becker (eds), Akten, Eingaben, Schaufenster: Die DDR und ihre Texte: Erkundungen zu Herrschaft und Alltag (Berlin 1997); P. Major and J. Osmond (eds), The Workers’ and Peasants’ State: Communism and Society in East Germany under Ulbricht, 1945–1971 (Manchester 2002); and K. Pence and P. Betts (eds), Socialist Modern: East German Everyday Culture and Politics (Ann Arbor, MI 2008). Volumes asking similar questions about state-society relations in former east-bloc states other than the GDR are C. Brenner and P. Heumos (eds), Sozialgeschichtliche Kommunismusforschung: Tschechoslowakei, Polen, Ungarn, DDR, 1945–1968 (Munich 2005); Crowley and Reid (eds), Socialist Spaces: Sites of Everyday Life in the Eastern Bloc (Oxford 2002); and Reid and Crowley (eds), Style and Socialism.
Quotations found in E. von Richthofen, Bringing Culture to the Masses: Control, Compromise and Participation in the GDR (New York 2009), 9.

John Ruskin, as well as Karl Marx, influenced Czech applied arts and industrial design. Useful studies of Czech applied arts during the interwar period include A. Adlerová, České užité umění (Prague 1983); J. Fronek, Artěl: Umění pro všední den, 1908–1935 (Prague 2009); and A. von Vegesack and M. Lamarová (eds), Czech Cubism: Architecture, Furniture and Decorative Arts, 1910–1925 (New York 1992).

Examples of the persistence of folk handicraft traditions in modern Czech visual arts are in the Interwar-era journal Drobné umění (the name of which was changed to Výtvarné snahy in 1926). Folk tradition’s persistent presence in modern Czech visual arts before 1914 is discussed in C.M. Giustino, ‘Rodin in Prague: Modern Art, Cultural Diplomacy, and National Display’, Slavic Review, 69, 3 (2010): 591–619.
Beneš Decree nr. 110/1945 Sb., 27 October 1945, ‘O organisaci lidové a umělecké výroby’. Found in Sbírka zákon Československé republiky, 49 (7 November 1945), 257–61.

The names of Czech Werkbund designers who later became involved in ÚLUV and EXPO ’58 are in Věci a lidé, 1948: Výtvarník ve výrobě: Výstava hodnotné tvorby členů Svazu českého díla a členů Ústředí lidové a umělecké výroby (Prague 1948).

On the purges see K. Kaplan, Die politischen Prozesse in der Tschechoslowakei, 1948–1954 (Munich 1986); and J. Pelikán, The Czechoslovak Political Trials, 1950–1954 (London 1971). A recent treatment is K. McDermott, ‘A Polyphony of Voices? Czech Popular Opinion and the Slanský Affair’, Slavic Review, 67, 4 (2008), 840–65. Studies of nationalization and collectivization include K. Kaplan, Majetkové zdroje KSČ v letech 1945–1952 (Prague 1993); and K. Jech, Kolektivizace a vyhánění sedláků z půdy (Prague 2008). For a published edition of Novotný’s memoirs see R. Černý, Antonín Novotný: Vzpomínky Prezidenta (Česká kamenice 2009).
Pernes, Krize komunistického režimu, 124.

Pernes, 125, 148. Goods for which prices were reduced included rice, tea, socks, soap and tobacco. See ‘O snížení maloobchodních cen spotřebního zboží: Usnesení Ústředního výboru KSČ a Vlády Republiky Československé z 29. března 1955’, in Od X. do XI. Sjezdu KSČ: Usnesení a dokumenty ÚV KSČ (Prague 1958), 77–9.
F. Kovárna, ‘Výroba včera a zítra’, Tvar (1948), 1–3.

The Union’s statute and changes in it during the 1950s are discussed in A. Primusová, ‘Skupina Máj v ideologických souvislostech’, in A. Primusová and M. Klimešová, Skupina Máj 57: Úsilí o uměleckou svobodu na přelomu 50. a 60. let (Prague 2007). Other important works on Czech art in the 1950s include M. Judlová (ed.), Ohniska znovuzrození: České umění, 1956–1963 (Prague 1994); M. Klimešová and M. Petříček, Roky ve dnech. České umění 1945–1957 (Prague 2010); A.J. Liehm, ‘Anmerkungen zur tschechischen Kultur und Politik, 1956–1968’, in D. Beyrau (ed.), Das Tauwetter und die Folgen: Kultur und Politik in Osteuropa nach 1956 (Bremen 1988), 107–22. M. Judlová and M. Klimešová are the same person.

M. Svašek insightfully discusses Czechoslovak artists who pursued abstract, non-figurative art during the 1950s in ‘The Politics of Artistic Identity: The Czech Art World in the 1950s and 1960s’, Contemporary European History, 6, 3 (1997): 383–403. She uses James Scott’s concept of ‘public’ and ‘hidden’ discourses to show ‘how hidden forms of resistance in the art world could develop into public acts of protest which, given certain developments on the international political stage, could generate domestic political change’ (384).

See also the work of Olga Karlíková and Jiří Mrázek, abstract painters who worked as textile designers. Examples of their textiles and paintings are in Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 300–03; and Tvar 10, 3 (1958).

Czechoslovakia signed the necessary agreement with the Belgian government in October 1955. The Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce (Československá obchodní komora) was charged with the pavilion’s creation and its president, František Adámek, was named General Commissioner. Twenty-four government ministries and dozens of visual artists contributed to the pavilion’s design and completion. Minister of Culture, František Kahuda, wrote to General Commissioner Adámek that, throughout their preparations, the organizers perceived that the world’s fair ‘would be an ideological competition between the capitalist states and Vatican, on one hand, and the camp of socialism and peace, on the other.’ Quotation found in Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 17–9.
Quotation found in Primusová and Klimešová, Skupina Máj, 57, 14–5. See also ‘Dopis výboru Ústředního svazu čs. výtvarných umělců všem členům a kandidátům’, Výtvarná práce (1955, no. 24), 1.

At the Congress Hrubín opened his statement about the importance of truthful expression for poetry, saying ‘It was an unhealthy and humiliating situation for Czech literature that, in past years, it was not possible to speak openly about its problems’. Found in ‘Z diskuse: František Hrubín’, Literární noviny, 28 April 1956, 10. Seifert was concerned with the writer’s role as the conscience of the people and about possibilities to speak honestly. He said, ‘It is nice, if poets push forward politics, but I dare say, it is less nice, if there is the opposite of this’. Literární noviny, 29 April 1956, 6.

Due to the Secret Speech – and again following the Soviet Union’s lead – the Czechoslovak Communist Party undertook a small number of liberalizing measures, including ceasing the playing of the Soviet hymn at the end of radio broadcasts and being more tolerant of religious organizations. See Pernes, Krize komunistického režimu, 150–1.

The exhibition catalogue for Kotík’s show, which some Communists condemned due to the abstract works in it, is Jan Kotík: Práce z let 1948–1956 (Prague 1957). On the Máj 57 exhibition see Primusová and Klimešová, Skupina Máj 57. A valuable introduction to non-socialist realist artists’ groups and exhibitions in Czechoslovakia around 1957 is Jiří Šetlík, ‘Počátky činnosti tvůrčích skupin a jejich význam’, in Judlová (ed.), Ohniska znovuzrození, 3–8.
Primusová and Klimešová, Skupina Máj 57, 17.

Michal Kopeček writes about revisionism and Party reactions to it in Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary in Hledání ztraceného smyslu revoluce: Zrod a počátky marxistického revizionismu ve Střední Evropě, 1953–1960 (Prague 2009).

NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor 1945-1989, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 150/195/2, ‘Výstava “Bydlení a odívání” v Parku kultury a oddechu Julia Fučika v Praze’. Originally, the displays were to focus on attracting foreign contracts, but then a month before it opened efforts were undertaken to make its offerings appealing to domestic shoppers, as well. The report complained that the shift of attention to include domestic shoppers hurt the exhibition’s success, because it reduced the array of goods attractive to foreigners.

O. Nový and J. Šetlík, Cubr, Hrubý, Pokorný (Prague 1962), 10. The three architects had been members of the Club of Architects (Klub architektů), an Interwar group of leftist modernist architects headed by Oldřich Starý.

Rostislav Švácha provides details about the impact of Khrushchev’s 1954 and 1956 speeches on Czechoslovak architecture in ‘Česká architektura, 1956–1963,’ in Judlová (ed.), Ohniska znovuzrození, 243. A contemporary Czechoslovak report on and response to the 1954 speech is G. Gradov, ‘Problémy naší architektury’, Architektura ČSR (1955), 331–36.

‘Úspěch československého umění’, Tvar (1958), 260–8. Cubr, Hrubý and Pokorný also said they attempted to use new untested materials, some of which proved problematic (see Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 110).

Nový and Šetlík clearly placed the building in the socialist system when they wrote, ‘The success of the Czechoslovak pavilion and exhibition was a victory of socialist humanism and our popular democracy’. See Nový and Šetlík, Cubr, Hrubý, Pokorný, 10.

The history of Czech glass during the Cold War, including international exhibitions of it, are discussed in the essays in H. Ricke (ed.), Czech Glass, 1945–1980: Design in an Age of Adversity (Stuttgart 2005). V. Wasmuth, who has an article in Ricke’s volume, recently published ‘České umělecké sklářství: Vystavování a export v socialistické “kulturní diplomacii” od 50. do 70. let’, in D. Kováč et al. (eds), Kultura jako nositel a oponent politických záměr: Německo-české a německo-slovenské kulturní styky od poloviny 19. století do současnosti (Prague 2010), 379–408.

‘Zápis o jednání poroty od 10.9.1956: Ideové řešení souboru objekt čs. účasti na Světové výstavě Brusel 1958 – architektonická soutěž (II. etapa)’. Found in NA, Fond Československá obchodní komora: KGK Brusel, Složek ‘Arch. soutěž ideové řešení, B-58’. Presently efforts are underway to catalogue this collection which consists of the papers of the Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce.

The turbine’s large size resulted from a competition at EXPO ’58 between Czechoslovakia and Austria, both of whom claimed the turbine’s inventor, Viktor Kaplan, as their native son. Kaplan was born in Moravia before 1914, which changed from Austrian to Czechoslovak hands following the First World War. The symbolism of the turbine and Makovský’s ‘New Age’ sculpture are presented in ‘Úspěch československého umění’, Tvar (1958), 267–8.

J. Hlušička, Vincenc Makovský (Prague 1979), 44–5. This book contains the most substantive discussion of Makovský’s life and work. Other works on the sculptor are J. Hlušička, J. Malina and J. Šebek, Vincenc Makovský (Prague 2002); and D. Šindelář, Národní umělec Vincenc Makovský (Prague 1963).

V. Kopecký, ČSR a KSČ: Pamětní výpisy k historii Československé republiky a k boji KSČ za socialistické Československo (Prague 1960), 473. Many others who contributed to Brussels are listed in the book as praiseworthy artists who enriched socialist culture. A new biography on Kopecký is J. Pávová, Demagog ve službách strany: Portrét komunistického politika a ideologa Václava Kopeckého (Prague 2009).

Makovský meanwhile devoted himself to teaching at prestigious institutions in Brno and Prague, and creating monuments for the Communist Party, including ‘The Partisan (1946, Zlín)’, on which a large hammer and sickle were mounted, and ‘The Victory of the Red Army over Fascism’ (Brno 1955).

One article on Kovář and the Zdeněk Nejedlý School of Applied Arts in Uherské Hradiště, where he taught, stated his machine design ‘makes possible the good maintenance (cleaning, etc.) of the machine and has a calming, “organic” and pleasant impression on the human’. See J. Kotík and J. Raban, ‘Nová práce uherskohradišťské školy’, Tvar (1955), 98.

J. Jindrová discusses decorations in the Hall of the Red Army in ‘Síň Rudé armády v Národním památníku na Vítkově’, Tvar (1955), 162–4. The National Monument on the Vítkov Hill, in which the hall stood, a memorial complex dating from the Interwar period, was originally intended to commemorate heroes of the Czechoslovak First Republic.

Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 82. In the English-language guide to the pavilion, which introduced the layout and content of each room, the sculpture ‘With a Unified Economic Plan the State is Directing All Activities towards the Public Good’ (and its corresponding constitutional principle) was translated as ‘All economic activities are controlled by the State by means of a unified economic plan’. Thus, through this brochure some ideology was overtly presented, although its introduction gave small attention to socialism and none to the Party. See the English version of the brochure, Czechoslovakia: Brussels 1958 (Prague 1958), 4.

It is interesting to note that the state symbol also appeared on the ceiling of the Hall of the Red Army in the National Monument atop Vítkov, for which Sychra had designed the mosaics. Thus, this cannot be called a new mode of display developed just for Brussels.

Not wishing to overwhelm visitors, Santar consciously kept signage in the pavilion to a minimum. He wrote, ‘It was necessary to respect the reality that the Czechoslovak pavilion is one of more than 120 pavilions at which viewers in Heyssel Park will look – viewers filled with impressions, tired and not ready to demand much from their brain coils’. Found in J. Santar, ‘Československá exposice na světové výstavě’, Architektura ČSR (1958), 684.
Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 83.
One Day in Czechoslovakia (Prague 1958).

A good example of the Czechoslovak Communist Party discussing everyday-life realities in the late 1950s are documents from the 16 October 1958 Politburo meeting on the living standard. The report and accompanying documents, labeled ‘Strictly Confidential (Přísně tajné)’, mentioned low wages, poor pensions and shortages of consumer goods and housing as matters to be addressed, and expressed particular concern for families with multiple children. See NA, Fond ÚV KSČ, A. Novotný, Carton 188, Politické Byro Ústředního výboru KSČ, no. 853/8, ‘Další opatření v rozvoji životní úrovně obyvatelstva’, 16 October 1958.

Quotation found in ‘Koncept porady, konané dne 5. ledna 1955 v ČOK Praha’, NA, ČOK (Kancelář generálního komisaře), uncatalogued collection. Švácha (in ‘Česká architektura, 1956–1963’, 244) addresses the discrepancy between representation and reality at Brussels when he writes, ‘[The] illusion of socialism [in the pavilion was] much more humane than that which everyday practice offered to ordinary people in real Czechoslovakia’.
K. Srp (ed.), Adolf Hoffmeister, 1902–1973 (Prague 2004), 202–3.
Výstava Vývoj vesmíru, země a člověka (Prague 1952).
NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 128/166/1, ‘Příprava čs. účasti na světové výstavě v Bruselu v r. 1958’.

Further Party dissatisfaction with the entry vestibule was expressed in a 15 September 1958 meeting of the Czechoslovak Politburo. There it was concluded that ‘with the use of the emblem of the hammer and sickle, the red flag, and the like’ the pavilion would have better emphasized that Czechoslovakia is a socialist country. Instead of the state symbol, with its Bohemian lion and Slovak silver double cross, there should have been ‘a portrait of the President of the Republic with a brief biography’. See NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954-1962, 190/261/5, ‘Zpráva o dalším průběhu Světové výstavy v Bruselu s vyhodnocením československých národních dnů’.
Photos are in Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 56–61.
Quotation found in Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 84.
NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor 1945-1962, 166/128/1, ‘Příprava čs. účasti na světové výstavě v Bruselu v r. 1958’.
Detailed descriptions of his machine designs at Brussels are in ‘Úspěch československého umění’, Tvar (1958), 275–86.
Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 55.
Ibid; Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 88–94.
L. Smrčková, ‘Sklo na Světové výstavě v Bruselu 1958’, Sklář a keramik (1958), 185.

An extensive study of Group 42 is E. Petrová, Skupina 42 (Prague 1998). Group 42 artists participated in cubist and constructivist international currents. After surviving the Nazi years, it was dissolved in 1948 when the Czechoslovak Communist Party took over. Theorist Jindřich Chalupecký was also a member. A more recent book treating Czech avant-garde art during the Second World War is H. Rousová et al., Konec avantgardy? Od mnichovské dohody ke komunistickému převratu (Prague 2011).

Josef Vydra, a Czech who founded the Bratislava School of Applied Arts and a member of Tvar’s editorial board, praised the Škrdlovice glassworks as ‘an example for our other manufacture’ due to its ‘environment of mutual trust’ between artists and technicians. See J. Vydra, ‘Výsledky práce škrdlovické huti’, Tvar (1955), 42–55. On Vydra and the Bratislava School of Applied Arts see I. Mojžíšová, ‘Avant-garde Repercussions and the School of Applied Arts in Bratislava, 1928–1939’, Journal of Design History, 5, 4 (1992), 273–9.

He also wrote a book on industrial design during the 1950s. See J. Kotík, Tradice a kultura československé výroby (Prague, 1955). The reviewer in Tvar praised the author for his ‘good knowledge of economic and social laws, as Marxist-Leninist science illuminated them’. See R., ' J. Kotík: Tradice a kultura československé výroby’, Tvar (1955), ix.
M. Pánková, Jan Kotík: Obrazy, 1939–1969 (Cologne 1991), 5–6. See also V. Lahoda, ‘Krotký modernismus’, in Judlová (ed.), Ohniska znovuzrození, 44.

‘Umění životní pravdy nedo libovůle?’, Rudé pravo, 13 April 1957, 3. Interestingly, not everyone agreed that Kotík’s work was abstract. See K. Hetteš, ‘Jan Kotík neboli snažení o současný výtvarný projev’, Tvar (1957), 88; and J. Císařovský, ‘Ještě k výstavě Jan Kotík’, Kultura, 25 April 1957, 6. Hetteš objected to labeling Kotík’s work abstract because, ‘decidedly in every case he evokes with his pictures a specific sensory experience’ and ‘it does not depart from a priori notions’.

NA, Ministerstvo školství a kultury, Carton 210, Sig. 22II: Brusel 58, ‘Zpráva o činnosti komise ministerstva školství a kultury pro přejímání uměleckých děl čsl. exposice na Světové výstavě Brusel 1958’, 2.
Ibid.

Primus, Art is Abstraction, 41. For many visitors from the East Bloc to the World’s Fair, seeing the international exhibition ‘Fifty Years of Modern Art’ was one of their most important experiences there. Czechoslovak Party authorities were critical of the abstract art on display in it. See Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 45–6.

Primus, Art is Abstraction, 41. After the World’s Fair, Kotík contributed works to the 1959 Czechoslovak Glass Exhibition in Moscow’s Sokolniky Park and the 1960 Twelfth Triennial in Milan for which he wrote the script. He remained very active in design and painting throughout the 1960s. In 1970, while he was a DAAD scholar in Berlin, the Czechoslovak Communist Party took away Kotík’s passport. In an interview with Verena Wasmuth (a historian of Czech glass), Jiří Harcuba (a glass engraver) suggested that Kotík and others were expelled ‘not because they painted abstractly, but due to their position on the invasion [of 1968]’. See Wasmuth, ‘České umělecké sklářství’, 405.

A Politburo report from 3 April 1959 criticized the display for failing to show the development of socialist farming (and criticized the entire pavilion for having too much abstract art). See KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954-1962, 214/291/43, ‘Zhodocení československé účasti na Světové výstavě v Bruselu’.
All quotations from Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 100.
‘Úspěch československého umění’, Tvar (1958), 275–9.
Musical instruments were also considered worthy of attention from industrial designers. See ‘Výstava hudebních nástroj’, Tvar (1955), 190–1.
J. Raban, ‘K novým pracím Antonína Kybala’, Tvar (1955), 217–8. A biography of Kybal with a discussion of his early postwar works is K. Hetteš, ‘Antonín Kybal’, Tvar (1955), 43–56.
Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 100–2; Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 57.

A Tvar article discussing the competition to decide which toys would be displayed said wooden toys had to be selected, because ‘we are unfortunately very behind in development and breadth of … plastic materials’. See M. Lhotský, ‘Soutěž na dřevěné hračky pro Světovou výstavu’, Tvar (1957), 56–9. For the 1967 World’s Fair in Toronto, Libuše Niklová’s plastic toys, designed around Jules Verne stories, won the competition. Still, they were not sent overseas, because it was deemed that ‘for the souvenir stall, where the collection was to be included, her toys showed too little allegiance to Czech customs and aspirations’. See M. Drgáčová, ‘Hračky Libuše Niklové’, Naše Pravda: List PV KSČ a rady ONV v Gottwaldově, 6 September 1966, 1. Quotation found in T. Bruthansová, Libuše Niklová (Prague 2010), 98.
NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 190/261/5, ‘Zpráva o dalším průběhu Světové výstavy v Bruselu s vyhodnocením československých národních dnů’.

The display included photos of the country’s many castles and chateaux, and a film of aerial flights over them, a reproduction of a richly vaulted ceiling from the town of Slavonice, a ten-metre long tapestry depicting over 100 castles and chateaux (which Kybal designed), a model of St. Catherine’s Chapel (dating from 1134; in Znojmo near Brno) with a reproduction of an interior fresco in it, and a recently restored wooden sculpture from the large gothic Levočský altar. The Gottwald quotation is found in Benešová and Šimůnková, EXPO ’58, 109.
Seifert’s poem is in Ibid. It began, ‘Time in its eternal cycle returns its dead to the edge of the shore …’.

The 15 September 1958 Politburo report on the pavilion criticized the Culture section for lacking ‘social reach’. There was no attention to mass organizations, especially the Revolutionary Trade Union Movement (ROH), socialist Czechoslovakia’s official trade union, and the Czechoslovak Union of Youth. The Pioneers, the red-scarf-wearing communist youth, were nowhere to be seen, it complained, adding that perhaps a Pioneer song could have been included. See NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 190/261/5, ‘Zpráva o dalším průběhu Světové výstavy v Bruselu s vyhodnocením československých národních dnů’.

N.M. Wingfield and L. Kirschenbaum discuss the cult of Fučík in ‘Gender and the Construction of Wartime Heroism in Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union’, European History Quarterly 39, 3 (2009): 465–89.
NA, Ministerstvo školství a kultury, Carton 210, Sig. 22II: Brusel 58, ‘Komise ministerstva školství a kultury pro posuzování uměleckých děl čsl. exposice na Světové výstavě Brusel 1958’.

‘Co přejete našemu umění do roku 1958?’, Kultura, 20 December 1957, 51–2. In this survey asking artists what they wished for Czechoslovak art during 1958, Bauch wrote, ‘[I wish] that artistic associations would be re-established according to various visual outlooks’. Kovář said, ‘I wish for our visual art that it permeates even further … there where the worker spends one-third of his life – at the workplace’. Bohumír Dvorský, President of the Artists’ Union, stated, ‘I wish that all artists would … lay foundations for works of such captivating beauty and emotional appeal like the forty victorious years of the Great October Revolution and Manifesto of Peace are for us. The understanding of this path is the path to socialist realism’.

NA, Ministerstvo školství a kultury, Carton 210, Sig. 22II: Brusel 58, ‘Komise ministerstva školství a kultury pro posuzování uměleckých děl čsl. exposice na Světové výstavě Brusel 1958’. For a photo of Bauch’s paintings on display see Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 72.

The 15 September 1958 Politburo report acknowledged that the restaurant had a good reputation at the fair, but criticized its high prices, saying even the Vatican’s pavilion had ‘an inexpensive snack-bar’ that workers could afford. NA, KSČ – Ústřední výbor KSČ, Praha – politické byro 1954–1962, 190/261/5, ‘Zpráva o dalším průběhu Světové výstavy v Bruselu s vyhodnocením československých národních dnů’.

The description of the decorations is in ‘Zpráva o průběhu prvního dne zasedání’, Rudé pravo, 19 June 1958. The text of Novotný’s speech is in ‘Zpráva o činnosti Ústředního výboru KSČ XI. Sjezdu a současné hlavní úkoly: Referát přednesený na XI. sjezdu KSČ prvním tajemníkem ÚV KSČ soudruhem Antonínem Novotným dne 18. června 1958’, 6. Insert in Rudé pravo, 19 June 1958.

The importance of industrial design for the Party’s apartment-building plans is specifically addressed in M. Jiránek, ‘Perspektivy průmyslového výtvarnictví’, Výtvarná práce, 24 August 1959, 1–2. Jiránek writes, ‘The mutual relation and indivisible unity of economic factors and creative work in the area of industrial design … is being further demonstrated to us in sharper light in connection with the goal of raising the entire level of manufacture 95 per cent by 1965 and especially in connection with the gigantic plan for the construction of 1,200,000 apartment units’. See also Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 204.

It was built upon two older institutes, Textile Creation (Textilní tvorba) and the Central Visual Center for Glass and Soft Ceramics Industry (Ústřední výtvarné středisko pro průmysl skla a jemné keramiky). ÚBOK employees other than Kotík included Jindřich Chalupecký, an art theorist, former member of Group 42 and curator of the Vacláv Špála Gallery during the 1960s, where important non-socialist realist artists exhibited their work. Another design institute created around the same time was the Controlling and Testing Institute of Goods Expertise (Kontrolní a zkušební ústav zbožíznalecký). See Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 224.
Poznatky spotřebního průmyslu za Světové výstavy v Bruselu, 1958 (Prague 1959), 12, 13, 15.
Ibid., 25.
Kramerová and Skálová (eds), Bruselský sen, 224.
Pernes, Krize komunistického režimu, 177.
J. Kotík, ‘O průmyslovém výtvarnictví’, Výtvarná práce, 5 May 1959, 1, 5.

See the work of the originator of this concept in A. Lüdtke, Eigensinn: Fabrikalltag, Arbeitererfahrungen und Politik vom Kaiserreich bis in den Faschismus (Hamburg 1993) and The History of Everday Life (Princeton, NJ 1995); and influential application of it for the GDR context in Lindenberger (ed.), Herrschaft und Eigen-Sinn in der Diktatur. An important new work on private life in East Germany is P. Betts, Within Walls: Private Life in the German Democratic Republic (New York 2010). See also J. McLellan, Love in the Time of Communism: Intimacy and Sexuality in the GDR (Cambridge 2011).

notes.title: Biographical Note
notes.p: Cathleen M. Giustino is Associate Professor of History at Auburn University. She is author of Tearing Down Prague’s Jewish Town, a study of the radical reconstruction of Prague’s former Jewish ghetto around 1900. She is currently writing a book-length manuscript on the fate of confiscated cultural property, including castles, chateaux, art and antiques, in Czechoslovakia from 1918 to 1980. This project grows out of her interest in the politics of architecture, design and display and research she completed while a Fulbright Research Scholar at the Institute of Art History in Prague.
